description:
The sell coffee beans only . No coffee.
Great tasting.
   They sell their coffee to the restaurants in
San Francisco.
author: Gayle G.

description:
Stopped her with a friend who's husband will ONLY drink this coffe - so I'm trying some now too - thought I'm not a coffee snob....
Small unassuming place - just 2 kinds of coffee.
Luciano was the man behind the counter and I assume the owner too.
He was adorable and fun.
Check it out!
author: Tina O.

description:
Coffee the way coffee should be!

I am coffee snub, OK? I heat up my coffee mug before I pour coffee in it! I toss the coffee out if it is too weak or if it has a less than desired aftertaste, I do NOT put anything but whole milk or cream in my coffee! You see what I mean?

I just drew an ugly picture of me as a coffee drinker, didn't I? That maybe true, but I drink no more than two or three cups of coffee each day and I want it to be damned right, specially the very first one in the morning.

Graffeo roasts their beans just right! I love their dark roast. It is good for drip coffee and it is good for espresso machines. They roast their beans right there, so when you walk in the heavenly smell of coffee hits you like an angel's wing! By 1/2 lb of their whole bean, take it home, grind enough for one serving*, make your coffee right away, and try it!

*Never, ever grind your beans and let them sit there for days. Coffee absorb smells like sponge. You do not want your coffee to smell like the salmon you had last night, do you?!
author: Afshin A.

description:
Quality?  5 stars.
Taste?  5 stars.
Concept?  5 stars.

The best coffee in NB for decades.  These guys supplied Mario's their coffee & espresso back when I worked there, & I loved the days when I was sent to do the pick up because the regular person was late or sick.  Yes, it was like a treat to come here. 

There's so much elegance in simplicity, & Graffeo keeps it simple.  Light, dark, half & half, or decaf.

That's it.

No drinks, no seats.  Buy your beans, & see you next time.  Like Liguria bakery a few blocks away, it's straightforward & uncluttered.  I really like that.

It was often said that the best espresso in NB was Illy & Graffeo.  

But, there isn't an Illy boutique in NB.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
This is my favorite coffee above all. I hope it never changes. And it's fun to go to the store in North Beach and buy it there from the owner. The smell of the fresh coffee that he just bagged for you is indescribable if you're a coffee fan. 

I don't believe he makes coffee drinks there...it's just a place to buy it. The San Rafael store may be different. Never been there.
author: Mister K.

description:
Graffeo got me addicted. 

I'm not a coffee expert nor a barista. I used to go into whatever coffee shops near me when I wanted a cup of Joe. Ever since I got my first pound of beans at Graffeo, my taste buds got elevated. I started to be picky about coffee. My home-brewed coffee tasted better than those from ordinary coffee shops. What a blessing and a curse. I can't just go into any coffee shops except for really good ones. That's how good the Graffeo beans are.
author: V L.

description: Love this place.  The owner/roastmaster is such a nice gentleman.  Every time I'm in San Francisco I have to drop by and pick up a bag of fresh dark-roasted beans.  They make a delicious cup with any preparation-- drip, aeropress, pour-over, French press, et al.  Enjoy!
author: Richard C.

description:
A Classic San Francisco Tradition. Two Stores: Available in North Beach, San Rafael and online - Graffeo has been a San Francisco Treat for decades.  High quality, rich, and worth every penny. We have a trick, he drives, pulls up, ( zero parking in No Beach Saturday mornings)  and I pop out and buy a month's worth. Heaven.
Next stop? xoxo Truffles...
author: Miami S.

description: I love their coffee . I live in Los Angeles and have it sent. I get whole beans and they are wrapped for freezing. Because they take all the water out of the beans unlike other places you're able to freeze the beans when they're thawed it's like they're roasted that day. I've tried different coffees down here in Los Angeles but I keep going back to Graffeos!
author: Rhonda G.

description:
This old roaster is often left out of the conversation about local coffee, which is criminal.

Their coffee is consistently delicious. 

The 50/50 dark/light blend is a coffee I daydream about. This coffee breaks a strict rule that modern 3rd wave roasters would never consider - combining different roast levels. But the results are so amazing, it's a rule I'm happy to break. (Caffe Vita's Queen City blend does this also) The result is such a full, rich, satisfying cup, that I'm not concerned with tasting the essence of a specific farm or elevation. 
Great as french press or pour over. 

It would be more fair to compare Graffeo's coffee to the likes of Starbucks or Peets - as it is similarly dark. It is far superior. This is the real thing. Highly recommended for coffee drinkers who prefer a more traditional coffee.
author: RK W.

description:
I got turned on to Graffeo around '86.  Cafe Flore at Market and Noe used them back then and I was a big Flore fan.  I started to buy it direct from the store in North Beach around that same time.  I am fortunate to have an office in Jackson Square so I walk up to Graffeo about once every couple of months to get bags of coffee from them.  

Their roasted coffee beans makes great espresso and American coffee. And you have to stick your nose in a bag of just roasted beans.  You will see why this is the best coffee in San Francisco, if not the world.
author: Tim P.

description: Smooth and dark and just nothing like a pound of whole beans from Graffeo. This coffee is delicious and well balanced and waaaaaay better than anything you can get at Starbucks, Peets or bitter Blue Bottle. There are no fruity notes in this Dark Roast. Just a pure, nutty, bold and smooth taste that is like no other.
author: Wendy R.

description:
As a recent college grad, who has discovered the joys of the peninsula commute and stop-and-go traffic, Graffeo's coffee is what's been getting me through my morning drive. 

Graffeo's motivates me to wake up a little extra earlier so that I have time to make a pot of coffee for my morning commute. And then paired with cream, the hotness, that smooth rich taste, you know that everything is all right in the world. 

Graffeo's has spoiled me to the point that returning back to my Starbucks and Peets' college days is unthinkable. Almost like committing blasphemy! 

Call me converted. 

PS - Graffeo sells coffee beans, so for those that want a quality cup of coffee, you're going to need some sort of coffee maker and a grinder.
author: Rebecca H.

description: I am hooked on their dark roast. My wife won't get out of bed until her Graffeo coffee is  ready in the morning. The only coffee I have had that was better( and I have tried them all) was my friend Dale's' on 5 acres above Kona ,which I paid $40 per pound and that was the price for a close friend.
author: Roger M.

description:
Why 3 stars? Because I didn't get the hype.

   ---   ---   ---

Seems like a cool enough place, but I was looking for legendary. Has anyone seen him?

This was a long time coming, as I'd wanted to try Graffeo for many years. It definitely wasn't bad, but it wasn't anywhere near as good as Blue Bottle. Maybe very expert roasters will disagree with me (which is totally fine) but I felt underwhelmed and was left asking, "why the hype?"
author: Brett N.

description:
I'm usually of the Stumptown/Sightglass/Ritual variety and lately I've grown to prefer Graffeo's beans for my at home coffee.  It's about $18 for a full pound.  None of that $18 for a tiny 12oz bag crap that the third wave roasters pull.  

All of the guys that work here are super friendly, and it feels like I've stepped back in time the minute I walk through the door. I love supporting this family run SF institution. Get the 50/50 blend of light and dark roast beans!
author: Alexis D.

description:
Best coffee in the world! I love the dark roast. Very friendly staff and old world vibe. Cool decor inside. 

Note: this is not a cafe, it's a roaster. You can only buy coffee beans or grounds here.
author: E. R.

description: The best coffee bean in San Francisco, without a doubt! You have the choice of 2 roasts, or a blend of both. I cannot say enough. I won't buy beans anywhere else! Why bother!!
author: Deanne F.

description:
I love dark, hecka roasted coffee. Here's the problem with it, though- it's easy to fuck up. The marketing of Peets and Starbucks and etc. have created a legion of people who think that gross burned-to-shit is what "real" coffee is "supposed" to taste like. 

For what a high-end dark, oily roast is "supposed" to taste like, I would refer you instead to Graffeo. You should also get a press pot and get your beans ground coarse to do this right. 

Living within walking distance of this location is what basically turned me into a coffee snob. It's not that I give a shit about the hipster image, I never want to "talk coffee" with anybody, that is the most boring shit on earth. It's that once you've had high-quality you just can't go back to the crap. 

For you if : you want a simple, dark, rich, high-quality coffee at a reasonable price per pound
Not for you if : you're one of these hipsters trying to turn coffee into bullshit "wine tasting culture" and want "varietals" and "peat notes" and all that nonsense.

Oh yeah, you can't actually get a cup of coffee at this location, they just sell beans. For a cup I think Cafe Greco and the little ice cream shop right nearby both serve it ... there's a small handful of places in the FiDi that do too but I forget the names offhand.
author: Jeremy H.

description: Excellent coffee, super place, and really great people! Feel so lucky to have this amazing place around the area. Next time I must try the chai
author: Kiran K.

description:
I'm fully convinced Graffeo sells magic beans. It's a pretty simple setup...they roast the beans and sell them immediately. The pound of the dark roast I got was "just roasted" and still warm when they put them in my bag. After going home a few hours later and pulling a shot of espresso, it made me feel like an all star barista with the way my cappuccino and iced lattes tasted.

I'll reassess after I'm through with my pound, but at this point, it'd be tough to go back to the major blue bottle and sightglass coffee.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Solid coffee with good service.  I mean, seriously, how many places in this town can figure out how to make a decent moccachattalatte without getting all flagrantly "hula-hoops are the best thing since sliced bread" about it?  Not many, am I right.  Only things is I wish it was a little more like Starbucks and a little bit less like Lemony Snicket, if you know what I mean.

Folks, if you know what's good for you, you'll get on the cable care and head right over thar!
author: Matilda S.

description:
We took a break from shopping in the Mill Valley, California the other day to have a leisurely lunch at Piazza D'Angelo Italian Restaurant. The food is really very good there, and if you're in the area, I suggest you give them a try - but that's another post.

This is really about the coffee that I finished up my meal with.

Normally, I am a huge fan of Peet's Major Dickason's Blend for my drip brewed morning coffee at home, and then when pressing the DeLonghi Magnifica into service - long about three in the afternoon - I'll sip some wonderful Illy. One sugar. And, either a biscotti or a madeleine. Never both. Savored, dipped and nibbled.

This is what being civilized is all about. it's not so much about stopping to smell the roses, as it is slowing down to appreciate the luxurious liquor that a fine roasted coffee bean can provide. It's heady. Sirupy. Sensual. Yes, Illy is rather expensive, I suppose - especially since I love the Illy Brazilian MonoArabica.  But really, a single? Occasionally a double? Certainly such a small cuppa love deserves putting the very best beans forward. No?

I digress. 

I have found a new love. Full-bodied. Not bitter. Bold yet silky smooth. Like a velvet glove being drawn lightly down one's spine. By candlelight. Motioning the waiter over, I had to know what this magical elixer was.

Huh? Graffeo? Never heard of it.

That's embarrassing, since I'm not exactly new to San Francisco. But Graffeo has been right there in North Beach since 1935 - roasting amazing dark, rich blends of Costa Rican, Guatamalan and New Guinea beans. Zagat knew about them, as did Wine Spectator! Sheesh. They positively swoon over Graffeo - gushing things like "best coffee around", "Number 1 Coffee", "best beans on the planet", and something about it being served at the Oscars.

This Graffeo outfit seems to be what companies like Peet's used to be about: Family. Passion. Quality. Don't get me wrong. I still drink Peet's, but the family finally sold out to a larger company from Europe, and we'll see what happens as the thing evolves.

It didn't take me long to check them out online - and get ordering. And, that's when I noticed something very interesting - that differentiates Graffeo from all the rest. They don't 'do' flavors. And they don't 'do' every variation and version under the sun - trying to capture every taste and palate out there in the usual coffee marketing strategy. They keep it simple - and very high quality.

Graffeo does dark, light and Swiss Water Process decaf. Period. They'll combine some half dark/decaf, half light/decaf - and a 3/4 dark or light over the decaf.

That's as far as they're going, thank you very much. Eight premium choices. If you need more, go get the floorsweep from that Seattle outfit. Come to think of it, I'm burnt out on the surplus of often mediocre choices that companies offer nowadays. Dozens of choices do not necessarily equate to quality.
author: Cynthia R.

description:
Americans live with the illusion of choice. The idea that 12 types of coffee is better than 2 seems inherently to make sense. Why have only one model of car when you can have 30? How about 8 salad dressing choices (you'll pick ranch in the end, anyway) or a build-your-own taco station with more types of salsa and fixings than there are people in the restaurant?

The effect of having too many choices is that we often have none at all, really. It's a paradox. But that makes it no the less true. Put me in front of a shelf of 60 shampoos, and my mind will turn to mush, I'll revert back to age 6, and I'll become suddenly vulnerable to TV advertising ... silky radiance! A full head of hair! You'll never get a second chance to make a first impression. Because you're worth it ... worth what, exactly? A $7.99 12 oz. bottle of foamy suds?

(Pause, as I get down from my soap box).

So, Graffeo, huh? Why trek all the way here for only 3 basic choices*: light, dark, or 50/50? Isn't there a Peets or Starbucks nearby where you can get your beans cheaper and in prettier packages? Why not head down to the Ferry Building and get a sexy-looking 8 oz. bag of Blue Bottle beans and flirt** with the super-chic baristas who will give you an impromtu "coffee consultation" to find just the right beans for your lifestyle after you've waited in a line 20 people deep? Why North Beach, why this place, which does not actually serve coffee and has a 1/2 pound minimum purchase? What if you want Sidamo beans or single-origin, shade-grown, fairly-traded, hand-picked, lightly caressed, and individually-washed beans from a 200-year old Coast Rican bird-friendly plantation high in the mountains?

Because. Just because.

Light, dark, 50/50, whatever. It's all good here. They've got caf class and they've got caf style. The secret is in the beans, the heat, and the knowhow that takes a generation or more to master. Scruffy-haired fly-by-night back alley roasters with college degrees can't match that, no matter how slick their under the radar screen advertising is. 

Try Graffeo once, and then you'll know. It won't be a one-time deal. Once you do Graffeo, you're in it for life. 

How's THAT for a choice, ya'll?

(*) Technically, they offer decaffeinated beans, too. But that would be like getting your crack with 50% less cocaine. And that's just wrong.
(**) For the record, I have never done this, by the way. Ever.
author: Bradley N.

description:
My absolutely favorite roast on the west coast. I'd take a pound of dark roast here before Blue Bottle, Intelligentsia, Ritual, or any of the other du-jours. I tell all my visiting friends to pick up a pound and none are disappointed. 

Rich, delicious and full-flavored. French press it and come with me to coffee nirvana.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I go there for coffee once every few months.

Why,
It's local.
The price is 16 per lb
Freshly roasted.
The customer service, the guy is always cheerful and will chat you up.

Why I don't go there more often
It's light or dark roast only.
No idea where the beans come from.
I order a lot of coffee from Maui using mail.

So, it's a great place to try, I usually rotate coffee roasters so I get new tastes.
So give it a try and support the locals.
author: Saar H.

description: It's ok, a little disappointed, especially in view of the price, I prefer Pete's coffee beans for my taste. Have to use quit  a bit to get a medium rich flavor.
author: Ron P.

description:
So long Starbucks' Goldcard! 
I have never had a more deliciously roasted coffee! Their delicious brew is served just down the street at Cafe Divine.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Graffeo has been around since 1935, is the old and wise rooster of artisan coffee.  In many ways they still do it better than other "neighbourhood" caffeine kids who sometimes show more hat than cattle.  Unfortunately, I don't get to the City often enough to repeat my previous and regular Graffeo habit when I used to live here.  But it is a real treat when I do return to North Beach.

I prefer the Dark Roast like I love Gayle: rich, full, and never bitter!
author: Eric B.

description: If you like strong Italian coffee (vs. that sour hipster coffee that has taken over SF) this is the place for you.  Impossible to find good traditional dark roast these days (and when these new fancy hipster "artisanal" bean companies say dark, it really isn't).  I refuse to buy Starbucks and Pete's has essentially become Stabucks since change in ownership (the coffee no longer good).  Thank goodness for throwback places like Graffeo - keeping it simple.  My new source for beans.
author: Ruth C.

description:
Long before I'd heard of Blue Bottle, Ritual, Stumptown, Starsucks (no, not a typo) or even Peets, Graffeo was a part of my life,  Growing up, the wonderful smell of their coffee roasting would waft down Columbus Ave.  I never had the chance to enjoy their coffee growing up (my family had Hills Brothers then Yuban as the coffee of choice way back when) but I always loved the smell.

In this day and age, when I get a chance to go into North Beach, I pick up the Dark Italian.  The richness of the flavor with a full body makes for a perfect cup.  And its not acidic like some coffee out there!  One of my sisters also loves their coffee so I try to pick up some for her when I can.  When she gets some of their coffee, she's in Heaven!  Its not cheap and its not overpriced.  Its oh-so-worth it.  When it comes to coffee, quality definitely should come before quantity.
author: J. P.

description:
French Press the Dark Roast. Let cool. Serve on ice.

BOOM.

Just your friendly neighborhood roastery.
author: Brian L.

description:
Love love love this place. I've only ever gotten the dark roast whole beans for my daily coffee fix and I've never looked back.

Just wish it was open on Sundays when I realize I'm running low but that's what I get for living in North Beach.
author: Scott C.

description:
Go In Just For The Aroma

Graffeo was founded in 1935 on the streets of San Francisco's Italian culinary capital, North Beach. It is one of North America's oldest artisan coffee roasters and remains a family-run company passed on down through generations.

Dark roast extraordinary coffee to take home or order online. They specialize in only two flavors so they are the best. Fluid bed roasted coffee beans smell distinctive. Perfecto! Taste brewed Graffeo coffee available at Mario's and Café Divine on Washington Street.

Originating from the finest plantations on Colombia, Costa Rica and New Guinea, Graffeo Dark is roasted to a high optimal temperature to release the deep character contained within the choice beans. It has received much critical acclaim for unmistakable rich flavor and unforgettable deep aroma. It is the coffee of choice for many of the world's leading eateries.
author: Desiree P.

description:
Coming from Seattle and moving to the Bay, I thought I was resigned to buy imported Italian roasts (Illy or Lavazza) or somehow get coffee beans shipped from Seattle. I was on Amazon all the time buying Lavazza (Illy's too expensive). I tried others such as Blue Bottle, Rituals, SF Coffee and even Scarlet City from the East Bay because of Jen who studied at my fav Seattle stand, Vivace. Yes, they are all good. Scarlet has great choices for different applications (moka, drip, french, or espresso).

But Graffeo coffee is better than Scarlet. Their roast is more even (almost as perfect as Illy) and has a lot of chocolate and caramel aromas with no burnt taste. It's like having Illy coffee without the outrageous price and pretentious can. Perfect for espresso.

Plain brown bag stamped with the word "Light". Simple and roasted with care.
author: Jasper L.

description:
When I was a wee lad (skip if you've heard me this say this before), I would walk past this place and breathe in DEEPLY to enjoy the coffee aroma. Of course, I wasn't a coffee-drinker then but I love italian and spanish coffee now, and when I pass by these days I get great memories of my time in both countries, mixed with my childhood. I recently walked in for the very first time to buy coffee for a friend who lives on coffee, and I don't regret it at all. I weaned her slowly off Starbrucks, doing the same with Peek's, and hoping she will visit me soon to sample true spanish coffee as I do, with milk and not water. Inside, you'll be asked which brand desired, then if you want whole beans or ground, then if ground, what will you use it with, and what type of filter will be used. wow. The coffee you purchase is in a plain brown paper bag, stamped with the type, and closed with thick plastic tape. Meet for coffee?

This place only sells one thing: coffee. For it to be here for so many years and still active in sales must be a statement of its quality and flavor.
author: Tony L.

description: In the 1970s, I used to stop by the long gone Coffee, Tea or ... at Ward Warehouse in Honolulu and sip Graffeo coffee while studying Japanese language texts before class.  By the 1980s, I was buying it by the pound to brew at home.  Then, in 1990, I moved to the DC area and spent years trying to find ANYTHING that tasted as good.  No joy.  Then the Internet came to work and it's one of the first things I looked up, after real estate in the south of France.  I started ordering by phone.  Now you can order on-line, too.  But, whenever I'm on the west coast, I make a trip to San Francisco just stock up on the Dark Roast.  It freezes well, although fresh is always the best.  Still, Graffeo frozen beans beat all the other swill out there, no matter how fresh.  You name it, I've tried it, *$$, Coffee Bean, Eight O'Clock, highly rated by Consumer Reports, Stumptown, Gevalia, Donut House, Peet's, Dunkin, Porto Rico, Kona, Blue Mountain, Caribou, Cafe du Monde, all the supermarket brands, and nothing is as good.   This last trip, November 2015, the price was $17.50/lb.  Pricey, but worth it.  BTW, this is a coffee store, not a coffee "shop."  Coffee is not brewed and served here.  You can buy whole beans or have them ground to your specs.
author: WonderWoman W.

description: For years this has been a favorite of mine. You know it has to be good when they can have store fronts in SF and Beverly Hills selling only beans!
author: Bill S.

description: Owner is super friendly and attentive, and the shop is charming. Goes without saying, but superb, freshly roasted coffee too! Definitely will be back!
author: Andrew F.

description:
First, don't come here expecting to order a cup of hot coffee, latte or espresso or to choose from a dozen or so offerings of single-origin and blended coffee beans. If you do, you'll be disappointed. 

Graffeo sells one kind of coffee: A mix of equal parts of beans from Colombia, New Guinea, and Costa Rica. 

You get to choose between regular or decaf; light roast, dark roast, or half 'n half (my preference).  No fancy packaging - the beans you order will be placed in a plain brown paper bag.

They roast beans in small batches, which means they're usually fresh and maybe even still warm, and they're careful not to roast the beans too much.  The downside is that on occasion they may run out of beans.  You might want to call them ahead of time to avoid disappointment.

Reasonable price: $14 lb.  

A second-generation family coffee-roasting business in San Francisco's North Beach neighborhood, the store itself is small and modest in appearance; but the coffee is rich, flavorful, and full-bodied. Another store is located in downtown San Rafael.  No long lines.
author: Terrence M.

description:
Ritual gets the hipsters queued up in long lines. Blue Bottle successfully courted the farmers market yuppie folks. For people who simply love coffee without the cliques or the lines, we have Graffeo.

They advertise as "Simply the world's finest coffee." While that might sound like hyperbole, I vouch for that claim.

What's even better is they charge very reasonable rates for coffee this good. The price-per-pound is a little more than Starbucks and significantly less than Ritual. 

And if you stop by the roasting location in North Beach, chances are the beans will still be warm when you get them.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Wanted to try their coffee over Peets coffee which I usually buy.  Picked up a pound each of dark and light roast today just after the store opened.  Was told the coffee was the last batch roasted the previous day.  

Made a 16oz mug of the dark roast in a French Press.  

Outstanding coffee!  Dark Roast has a very strong after taste (which I like).  
Will try the Light Roast later which I know will be good (with maybe a different effect).

They offer only 4 coffee products:
* Dark Roast
* Light Roast
* 1/2 Dark 1/2 Light
* Decaffeinated (Swiss Water process)

They have locations in San Francisco and San Rafael.  They formerly had a location in Beverly Hills (I'm sure the celebrities down there didn't like that happening).  

If the New York Times on the opposite coast gives a grand review of this coffee, you know this coffee has to be tried.

They perform roastings Monday thru Friday.  The stores are open on Saturdays and closed on Sundays.

Still have that taste in my mouth a half hour after finishing my cup...
author: Bernie B.

description:
Bar none, the best coffee roaster in The City. No frills - just delicious, fresh roasted beans with an uncanny consistency. Choose your poison, dark or light and enjoy.

Classic North Beach location, staffed by classic "North Beachers" from the old days. Best to go mid day weekdays, parking is easy and the beans are warm and fragrant.

"Character" counts! So do "Characters". This place has both...
author: J G M.

description:
Real coffee for real people
Sometimes the old things are the best
Absolutely delicious coffee from tried and true artisan roasters
Get it home and make yourself a drip coffee
Try it black without cream and you can taste the difference
Full bodied without the acidity and strong hints of cocoa
author: Rrr X.

description:
Someone mentioned they are never out of coffee...but guess what? They have been running out of coffee. 

Closing the so cal location doesn't help either. We like the coffee but the ordering online/wait/shipping is too much. 

Good luck Graffeo. Maybe one day things will be better.
author: Vince W.

description:
Excellent Beans!
Two choices make it simple and quick to get in and out of there. People do sometimes have a hard time selecting light or dark. What cha gonna do?
author: Liz J.

description:
Wow - I'm both sad and elated that I just found this place.  I don' t think I'll ever have any other coffee in the house again.  It would be an insult to my Bialetti Moka pot to desecrate it with anything less than Graffeo dark roast.

I'm so sorry for the less worthy coffee I've put in it before.
author: Dave H.

description:
Since a young man the smell of this roaster and the brew at home,
has always meant family.
Forget about Petes Italian roast, this company knows the blend and the roasting that's tradition.
Their dark roast is our favorite.
Family is Family so when in north beach swing by for a few pounds to take home on the plane or the car.
The Beverly Hills location closed sad to say.
Probably one of the finest roasters left in America without all the hype.
author: John W.

description:
Best coffee bar none. In North Beach, a coffee mecca. But a little North off Washington Square on Columbus. Anyhow i get the dark roast ground for a Pavoni. They actually set the grind for your specific machine and it works perfectly in my Pavoni every time.
Beautiful crem -a. If I can't make it to the city I buy on line and have it shipped.
author: Bill F.

description:
This place is so convenient - 2 blocks from my apartment - and I love their products, especially the dark roast.  Nowhere else can you buy coffee beans that were roasted an hour earlier.

That said, I've had various experiences with the staff.  Most of the time, the gentlemen there are friendly.  The catalyst for this review was the latest of two whack experiences I've had.  The first one was while I was in the store and overheard an employee making an inappropriate comment about a religion - not one that I preach but still offensive.  The second was when I called on a Saturday morning to see what time they close.  What I got in response was, "Are you serious?!", as if my question was unreasonable.

I'm done with the aura of arrogance that I sense every time I'm go there.  It's only coffee and with so many other good options available, I'm disappointed with Graffeo.  While I love to support small businesses, I'd rather buy Peets.
author: Raja B.

description:
The guy who sold me the beans was really nice, & the storefront w/ the giant cup is cool, but I didn't think these beans were anything special.  

I find Trader Joe's bay blend to be bolder/richer than Graffeo's dark roast, for what it's worth.
author: Holly F.

description: The search for the best coffee in the United States ends here.
author: D.B. C.

description:
An icon.  A landmark.  An institution.  A...nother day in North Beach.

Whatever else your opinion of Graffeo, you gotta admit ordering is easy.  You get exactly two choices: light roast or dark roast (ok ok, you can custom blend them in any ratio you want).  So if you're going to be a Graffeo regular, you'd better *really* like this stuff, because it'll probably still be the same in another 75 years.  Service is simple and pleasant, but at $13.75 it's some of the priciest beans I've seen.  And while it's terrific coffee, I still think Castro Cheesery has a superior (and cheaper) blend or two up their sleeves.    Still, whenever I take foodie tourists on the inevitable Russian Hill - Coit Tower walk, Graffeo makes an excellent point of interest.
author: Wes M.

description: I consider myself  as an avid espresso drinker.  I pull my own shots from home using a mazzer grinder and an izzo duetto espresso machine.  I have tried many different beans from independent roaster (veltons, urth, paradise, portolla,chris coffee and etc..).  I did not find anything special about these beans.  When paying $16 for a pound of coffee one can expect essence of chocolate, caramel, citrus, floral, tobacco and etc, I found none in these.  Save yourself a few dollars in these days of inflated gas prices and get yourself some Folgers, you will not be able to tell the difference.  As a public service, do not let looks and snootiness fool you..  BTW, I had the same result as a pour-over!  And Ideally coffee should be brewed at 200 degree give or take about 2 and not 185 degree (sour) wrong info to me as a customer.
author: George V.

description:
Best coffee in san fran or anywhere - I want to eat this coffe like food it is so good, can't drink enough of it!  - 
go with the dark roast
author: scott P.

description:
Today my friend D. took me to Graffeo in North Beach, and gave me a tour of the coffee roaster which he built 17 years ago. It's one of the only fluid bed roasters in the world, where the coffee beans are treated like fluid.

I don't know if you've ever had Graffeo. I was turned onto it recently, and I think, quite frankly (and this is no bullshit, as I've had my share of good coffee), it's the best coffee I've ever tasted. It reminds me a little of what I like about Kona coffee. It's better than Blue Bottle, much better, and I think Blue Bottle is excellent, though my friend D. thinks otherwise. And he's a coffee expert among experts.

It's not grassy, like San Francisco Bay coffee. It's not burnt like Charbucks. It's nutty and chocolatey and smooth. It's got that something going on that's undefinably delicious, almost offputting. It's so good you can't believe it, and believe it you will, at least I did. And now I'm a convert.

Ruch Reichl of the New York Times once called it the best coffee in the world. It's a combination of New Guinea, Columbian and Costa Rican beans.

D. described the process of the fluid bed roaster to me. It'll roast 3 loads in an hour, a load being 180 lbs. It's got a vacuum that sucks the beans up through a pipe into... I'm not a mechanical engineer, and since I'm slightly tipsy, I can't recall the terms D. used as he led me through, but I can assure you that if you like coffee and you're in San Francisco, you'll be pleasantly blown away by Graffeo.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
Easily some of the best coffee in this town. They won't just let any clown sell their coffee either, you have to have your act together. I used to manage Cafe Ariana in the showplace design center back in the day(12 years ago). Every Tuesday they would deliver and it was like being back east. Some cool Italian delivery guy would hang out and have a cup of espresso just to make sure our machine worked properly and we were not ruining the joe.
 
Screw McCoffee...the two to three popular coffee franchises know who I'm talking about. They couldn't wipe Graffeo's ass. 

Werd em' up!
author: Bill M.

description:
I'll drink Graffeo coffee, or I won't drink coffee at all.

Well, that's not entirely true. Let me amend: I'll use Graffeo coffee beans at home, or I won't make coffee at home at all. I do drink non-Graffeo coffee at Cafe Grecco, the only cafe I'll patronize.

I tend to find what I like and I stick with it.  Graffeo's beans suit me well.  I use the light roast beans.  They're rich and not bitter.  I've been to Blue Bottle, I've stood in the long-ass line surrounded by hipsters and seriously I cannot see the reason for such hype.

Graffeo kicks Blue Bottle's ass.  The counter men are always friendly, both to me, and to my son, when I send him there to buy our beans.  That's a big deal, because a lot of people treat kids like utter crap, and then he gets upset and refuses to go there again, thus limiting the number of errands I can send him on, which sucks.

Graffeo: best coffee, best service, simply the best.
author: Jamie C.

description:
There used to be a time when the shopkeeper was a friend, historian and storyteller...For more than 15 years, I have been drinking Graffeo Coffee...how lucky SF is to have Luciano to tell jokes, tell me a little history, and sell me a couple pounds of coffee! BTW-The best restaurants in town DO serve Graffeo!

NEW RULE: Support these jewels in our city's fabric. Buy ALL your coffee here.
author: Ron G.

description: Even though I now live in Woodside, we still head to Graffeo to buy coffee beans whenever we can... And it ends up being often. Forget all the hip SF roasters- these guys are the best. Flavorful, complex and very fresh.
author: Karla R.

description:
Graffeo roasted coffee beans are quite likely the best in the West. This is not a caf. In a way, such is rather unfortunate considering their prime location. Nonetheless, they focus on one thing, and that one thing they do right. If you want a tatse of their coffee, simply head over to Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store on the corner of Union & Columbus and ask for a single espresso. Add a small spoon of sugar if you like, and tell me if this isn't the best espresso around.

Since I love coffee, and I do not own a professional espresso maker, I instead brew Graffeo coffee in a drip coffeemaker. I buy one pound of half & half at a time. I have it ground ahead of time, since it really does not affect the quality as long as you store it in an air-tight and light-tight container, and as long as you use it within a week or two.

Graffeo coffee is $13.25 per pound. It is not cheap, but remember, most of the coffee you buy is not sold in one pound bags - they are usually 12 ounces. The price definitely holds up to the superior quality.
author: Geoffrey B.

description:
There was a time when a man could go in to a store and order  goods by the pound to be packaged in brown kraft paper and perhaps tied up with that red and white string that only merchant men could find.  The man behind the counter had a scale and an apron and maybe even a moustache, and he knew the name of your child.  He stood watch over a large block of lard and several barrels of grain, and when he thanked you for your purchase it was genuine and heartfelt.

Graffeo Coffee Roasting Co. is still that place.*

Do not go in to this place expecting a nonfat double-foam half-caf caramel macchiato because they only have three 55-gallon bins filled with delectably roasted coffee beans behind the counter.  The roasts are "dark," "light," and "decaf," with the latter implying a turn-of-the-century modernity that seems at odds with its surroundings.

If what you desire is a fantastic bean, I recommend Graffeo without reservation.  If what you desire is a fantastic bean and an authentic surround in which to purchase it, then Graffeo has no peer.

*Note: I can not recall if the man currently has a moustache.
author: Mike M.

description:
Don't get me wrong. I love Blue Bottle and Ritual other poodly roasters that buy sustainable-shade-grown-free-trade-no-animal- testing beans in microlot quantities. Really, I do.

In fact, I love them so much that when a friend led me to Graffeo a few months ago, I was underwhelmed. Two roasts: light or dark. That's your selection?! And there's no write up telling me to look for notes of wilted hazelnuts or seared raspberries? Feh!

To be polite, I bought a half-pound of beans -- and I haven't bought coffee beans anywhere else since. Graffeo's are consistently delicious and consistently excellent, and the service is always pleasant and efficient.

Oh, I'll still go to the poodle places. Graffeo's, after all, sells beans, and that's it -- you can't buy a cup of coffee there, much less anything with art poured on top.

But for my day-in, day-out grind, it's Graffeo's, baby.
author: Jim H.

description:
I have yet to go by the shop but enjoyed their beans from many miles away.  One of my former employers, Our Daily Bread, would brew their beans ever morning and I have to say it was the best coffee in town at that time.  

In SF, we're almost as fanatical about coffee as Portland but not quite.  I have stop saying best when it comes to coffee.  Enjoyable.  Above palitable.  Good.  These are all better ways of describing coffee and Graffeo has a really good roast.  Definitely get my vote!
author: Augie S.

description: Consistent, high quality coffee beans.  They have been running out of beans frequently lately so it's best to call before you go.
author: Buddy M.

description: I first started going to their Beverly Hills store until it closed. I now order on the phone and they ship right away. It is the best coffee. No bitter after taste. Occasionally I find myself in San Francisco and go by and order the coffee there. No other coffee like it.
author: Colin B.

description:
This is the reason I am up in the city at least once a month.  

$14 for a pound of the dark roast, you can just get 1/2 pound.

Me, I always order the same thing, 1/2 pound of their dark roast whole beans.   Grind it at home for maximum freshness.

My morning coffee is not the same with any other bean.
author: Amy F.

description:
Their motto is "Simply the world's finest coffee" is no hype.  Any company that can survive since 1935 by selling 3 kinds of coffee has to be doing something right.

Dark roast, light (which I personally have never tried) and an amazing decaf is all they need.  You only have to tell them what kind of filter and coffee maker you have and they grind it to perfection.

Twice a month I trek down Russian Hill and buy 2 pounds, one for home and one for my office.  Other times I have to take a pound as gifts to friends who ask for it.

Don't expect a complimentary cup when buying, you're lucky to get a shopping bag but they have perfected the art of coffee roasting and expose Starbucks for the dreck it really is.

You cannot go wrong with this coffee.
author: Stitch H.

description: Waking up to a cup brewed with Graffeo half dark half light after many years.  Oh so good.  Simply coffee beans at the location in North Beach.  Nothing brewed.
author: Ash A.

description: i have my buddy pick me up 2 pounds every time he makes it up north. BEST COFFEE YOU WILL EVER DRINK.
author: Chris b.

description: I am still in the gifting mode until next week, and a pound of the Graffeo Coffee for my bean-head friends always impresses the roast out of them. I look like a genius for getting them a 'specialty' coffee. Graffeo also ships directly from their web site, so that is an easy option for Mister Wait 'Til The Last Minute To Shop. I will buy some for myself for special occasions, and I like to drinks it in their store when I am in the neighborhood.
author: Drake F.

description:
I'm stunned. This is the only less-than-4-star review for this place to date.
Why?


The good:
 - Local.
 - Fair prices.
 - Freshly roasted.
 - Far better than Peet's or Starbucks (those would be .5 stars).
 - Unlike Blue Bottle, they've never been out of coffee. 


The marginal:
  - Selection? Nope. Sorry. 'Light' or 'Dark'. But you know, I can dig
minimalism. On another hand this means that this place can never
ever sell great coffee. Varietals. Single origin. Cup of excellence. 
Who called me a snob? You?! Well, sir, you are correct!


The bad:
 - No as good as either Blue Bottle or Ritual or Barefoot. 


In the end, once a year or so, I stop by and buy some coffee. And in the
end, once a year or so, I wish I went to one of the three above 
mentioned places.
author: Max R.

description:
Strong and not bitter.
Absolutely delicious and worth the trip to North Beach if you live elsewhere in the city.  
Best beans I've ever used.
author: Sharon G.

description:
I remember when they would sell this coffee in St. Helena at a little store on Main Street.

I miss my Graffeo's coffee...no frills or silly flavors... just the best coffee ever.

Sadly, everytime I try to go there it's closed.....sigh.
author: Eliza K.

description:
I live very close to Graffeo but I swear I never seen it open! The fact that they don't open on Sundays probably was the reason. I was looking for a place to have lunch on Yelp, I searched for restaurants in North Beach and this place popped up. I called and they were indeed open!! I am a coffee snob, I have a Rancilio setup in my place in south bay and I get my beans from Barefoot, I pull ristrettos with a bottomless portafilter with a triple basket from Chris Coffee. Anyway, when I'm up in the city on weekends I have to depend on coffee shops for coffee, and all the coffee shops in my neighborhood suck! Seriously, some are great places to hang out or to use the free WiFi but the coffee just plain suck. (I have very high standard though)... Only place I like is Ritual but it's too damn far from where I am.

Anyway, I stopped by Graffeo and copped half a pound of coffee, I don't have a grinder up here so I asked him to grind them, I thought about how I would brew them, I decided french press is probably the best and cheapest way to get quality coffee, so I went with that. With my 1/2 lb of grounds in my bag, I walked to Macy's and copped a small french press, went home, brewed myself a cup, holy shit, this dark roast is THE SHIT! This is awesome coz I literally live 2 minutes from them and they sell by 1/2 lb so I can have fresh grounds all the time!! :)

Next week I'll cop half a pound of whole beans and bring it to south bay for the week... Barefoot is great but I'm too lazy to drive down there from where I live...
author: Andrew N.

description:
Oh Graffeo beans I adore you, so strong yet never bitter, rich but not pretentious, your sublime aroma brightens my day. No other bean can come close to your well balanced glistening goodness, you've spoiled me. 

I am so sorry that I must destroy you, pulverize and scald each and every one of you, to partake of your nectar. But you forgive me, I know because you never cease to agree with me, unlike so many of your beany brethren who insist on having the last word.

(FYI: There is also a Graffeo in San Rafael with equally good beans, for those in the Northbay: http://www.graffeo.com/)
author: GIR ..

description:
My boyfriend and I make our weekly trek to Graffeo to get a 1/2 lb of the best beans for the freshest, best cup of coffee. Believe the hype; Graffeo is all that is cracked up to be.  

P.S. If you're going to get the best whole beans, please dump the blade grinder and splurge on a burr grinder.  You won't believe the difference it makes.
author: Kim S.

description:
This place is NOT a cafe, it's a roastery (if that's such a word), in case you were mistaken like me.  

No big deal.  I live a few blocks away.  Walked over to the Bohemian Cigar Bar (per friendly owner's recommendation) and got a fresh cup there of the dark roast.  They get their coffee from Columbia & New Guinea.  

Gave it 5 stars since I don't want to ruin a good thing going, like to support neighborhood businesses, and have yet to try it freshly brewed with real creme at home.  The coffee at Bohemian was IMHO 4 stars.  The best I've had ever was in Costa Rica.
author: K G.

description: If you forget your password there is no help!! Really frustrating especially if you are on zipped up on their delicious light roasted coffee!
author: Channell W.

description:
I read the reviews and thought I would give it a shot.   I expected to find a list of coffee choices, Sumatran/Ethiopian/Espresso, etc.  But they give you two choices.  Dark or Light..  I bought the dark roast, thinking we will see.  Completely blown away. 
Probably the best coffee I have had to date.  Wonderful aroma and strong without the bite that pinches your nose.  A bit pricey, but worth the extra money.
author: Michael B.

description: Dark, light, how much?  Delightful coffee.  I also really enjoy the oversized fake brunch items on the tables in the windows.
author: William B.

description: This is good coffee.  There are plenty of really good places to get coffee in the area...but Graffeo is different.  You won't run into hipsters with elitist attitudes here.  That alone is worth it for me.  Also, the coffee just smells delicious!
author: Gorn Z.

description:
Best roaster in town, 
G's beans help to get it right, 
Perfect cup at home.
author: Brian J.

description: This is a fairly smooth cup of coffee. I was very excited to stop in here for a cup of coffee, and very disappointed to see they don't sell "cups-to-go". However I bought half a pound of their dark roast and have been brewing it at home in my French Press. I'd like to go back and buy some of their light blend to compare.
author: Heidi B.

description:
simple list of the best coffee roasters
1. graffeo
2. House of Coffee (Sunset district & B-game)
3. Peet's Coffee

this location is also part of my North Beach tour for out of town visitors to SF. tell Luciano hello when you see him. He's the one with glasses and the warm smile.
author: Jeff W.

description:
many years ago, my favorite coffee place in san jose opened, vigal coffee. william the owner opened his own shop after working here so i thought i'd check it out.

graffeo is the best. if you want attitude, go to peet's, if you're buying a, um, lifestyle, go to starbucks. for coffee, you come here.
author: Brian B.

description: Simply the world's finest coffee, and it lives up to the hype.  Light roast or dark.  Don't show up expecting to order a latte; or any prepared coffee for that matter.  All these guys do is roast and sell the best beans you'll ever take home.  Trust me when I say that this is one of those places you turn your friends onto.  Most of mine are getting 1/2 lb bags for Christmas.
author: Joshua B.

description:
Sooooo good!  I like a coffee shop that has three items - dark, light and half and half.  They do what they are EXCELLENT at - roasting beans.  they don't even brew it!  

I have upped my order to 2 lbs half and half because my addiction grows.  Living in Berkeley, I have to get my fill when I'm in SF.  I grind it myself, but they do a great job of customizing your grind based on your coffee making machinery.

Their coffee tastes just like coffee smells - roasty, toasty, mellow and awesome.

ps - I recently tried blue bottle.  ok, but doesn't hold a candle to Graffeo!
author: julie a.

description:
One of my favorite places.  Too bad they don't brew at the store.  I send a couple of pounds to my friends in Honolulu, every once in a while.  I'll take my dark roast over anything that the state of Hawaii has to offer, including Kona.

Mailing tip:  get a flat rate envelope and stuff a one pound package.  The post office is located a couple of blocks away on Stockton Street on the east side of Washington Square.  This is the cheapest way to share.
author: Collin W.

description:
When I was a child, my mom and I would walk past this roastery frequently on our way to Chinatown.  I loved the smell on roasting days then and I love it now.  

Best coffee PERIOD.
author: kenny k.

description: I make the trip into North Beach every couple of weeks to buy this stuff.  It is so fresh and will never turn out bitter.  Friendly and fast service.  The dark is not as roasty as french roast, but has better body, which I prefer.
author: John K.

description:
Without caffeine of some type in the morning, I am scarcely human.  I will bite you and not in a friendly, 'Lets see what else pops up' kind of way.  

Graffeo coffee is a humanising, rational way to mitigate my caffeine dependence.  That and it's the best possible morning coffee available in San Francisco (sorry Trieste, you're for later in the day).
author: Stephen N.

description:
WORLD'S WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE!!!

Decent coffee but their haughty self important attitiude is inexcusable.
I have bought from them for many years. However they lost /forgot my last order and when I contacted them, I received no response to three e-mails, no apology and no compensation. BUY ELSEWHERE...THEIR COFFEE IS NOT THAT SPECIAL.
author: john e.

description:
After sampling beans roasted by a number of Bay Area coffee heavyweights (Ritual, Four Barrel, De La Paz, Barefoot, and Philz), I have to say that Graffeo's dark roast just might be my favorite.   These beans combined with an Aeropress = beautiful, rich coffee perfection.  

The retail store itself is not much more than a counter, and as noted by other reviewers, there's not much in the way of choice.  But the service is friendly, and -- light or dark -- you can't go wrong with the beans.
author: S P.

description: I have been buying coffee from Luciano for 25+ years. Nothing else comes close to Graffeo's Dark Roast. As their bags announce, "Simply the world's finest coffee"
author: Ira S.

description: I get a 1/2 lb of fresh ground every week.  They have 3 choices, light, dark and mixed and all 3 are great.  The light is really strong and a cup will keep you juiced for the morning.  Most restaurants in North Beach serve Graffeo, ask for a cup, it's good.
author: Ken F.

description: The only place outside of Italy where I can trust they will provide the correct grain for my Bialetti caffetiera (stovetop press).
author: Molasses C.

description: I grew up in North Beach with the aroma of roasting coffee waifing through the neighborhood (Malvina, Trieste & Graffeo to name a few).  When I was 14 or 15, I purchased my first ground beans from Luciano's father.  There were only two blends then: dark roast and light roast (American roast) as it was referred.  The dark roast actually has less caffeine than the light roast according to Luciano's father.   Over the years, Luciano has kept to his father's tradition and the quality is consistent.   Graffeo Dark Roast is the gold standard - anywhere.
author: Joe R.

description: I pick up coffee for my office here every week. They have a simple selection... Light Roast or Dark Roast... Whole bean or ground. We have some serious coffee snobs in my office and everyone loves this coffee. They don't actually serve coffee here but if you want to try their coffee just go to the cafe next door.
author: Thel D.

description: This is absolutely the best coffee around. The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf is a close second, but the thing that knocks me off my feet about Graffeo is that the flavor of the coffee is so out of this world good that it can get away with being consumed black (no sweetener or cream). Wish that more restaurants would select Graffeo as their house brand.
author: Anne H.

description: Graffeo is without a doubt my favorite coffee roaster. They don't sell 10 different roasts and blends. They hold to a simple principle: do one thing and do it well. Well, you actually get two choices - light or dark roast. I go for the light because it suits my taste. I think it's a perfectly balanced coffee. The other reason I support them is that they are good people and I like going in there. They are always friendly and cordial.
author: Mark M.

description: This is probably add odd review in that I've never actually BEEN here. Their coffee is hella good, though! My fiancee and I had it down the street at North Beach and I was blown away. We're definitely visiting this place sometime soon.
author: Cristian C.

description: I first had Graffeo coffee at Tabla in New York City a few years back.  We were there for my birthday, and the uber-wonderful waiter Ben (I can't believe my sister remembers his name) gave me a half-pound of the Graffeo coffee after I commented on how good it was.  So, I was thrilled to discover Graffeo right here in North Beach -- three thousand miles from my first taste.  So good, I would have come here from New York just for it. Luckily, it's only a few blocks from home!
author: Jess S.

description: I was introduced to Graffeo's Coffee years ago and I have to say it is some of the best coffee I have ever had. I am a bit of a coffee snob since I owned a coffee bar for a couple of years. We carried Torrefazzione which is superb as well but there is something about Graffeo's that is un-matched. I am opening a gourmet kitchen and food store soon and Graffeo's will be the signature coffee in my store...that is if they wholesale. :-) . Graffeo's has a signature flavor all its own. They never over roast their beans so the flavor is smooth but rich. Makes great espresso.
author: Kathleen L.

description: Thank you for selling to Molly Stone's in Greenbrae!  I know you've been sending my orders via UPS which works out great, but nice to know  I can run into Molly Stone's next to my office  for Graffeo Coffee now. Yay!
author: linda w.

description: This place is as simple as it gets.  Coffee for sale in 1/2 lb increments or more.  Choose from light or dark roast.  Go home with very good coffee.  I'm definitely a fan.
author: Tim S.

description: I love this place. I love the simplicity and the folks who work there are so nice every time I go in there. I love the dark coffee and I drink it everyday. It is consistently great.
author: Jaime C.

description: Tried the dark roast in a french press... This is amazing coffee that has great drinkability. Might be the best coffee I've ever had, and is certainly the best dark roast.
author: R E.

description: 4 stars for their excellent coffee.  I just made some espresso on this old Breville machine and can confidently say that I didn't think I could ever make espresso this good.  The coffee might be 5 but I don't consider myself a coffee aficionado since I know only 2 flavors: good and bad.  The extra star is for the service - friendly and helpful.  Yet another to love this great city by the bay.
author: Mike C.

description: I was turned onto Graffeo as I'm a barista and it's what we use at my work.  Now... there are sights, sounds and smells that I associate with work and sometimes they're unpleasant as work can be... unpleasant.  The smell of the wonderful bags of Graffeo coffee are happily not something I have a negative connotation with as a result of being surrounded(knee deep in it) at work.  A few months ago I wasn't even drinking coffee, It'd even really been years ago back in Seattle that I was last a coffee consumer.  Now every morning I'm at work without fail I make myself a single shot packed tight topped with just a touch of steamed soy...  perfection.
author: Crispin M.

description: My first five-star review! Over the years I've sampled dozens of different beans, and finally I've alighted on a source I'll return to without trepidation (with the caveat that change is the only constant). The beans create fantastic espressos, at least for my grinder and machine (a Rancillio). The espresso emerges the color of caramel, the flavor is richly chocolaty, yet balanced and smooth. Graffeo dark roast consistently offers me 'all crema all the time' espressos, unlike Blue Bottle and various other artisanly-selcted beans that I've tried. Fortunately, the caffeine content seems low, for I've yet to suffer the jitters, unlike with some other dark roasts I've tried. The avuncular man behind the counter further validated my joy at discovering these beans; I would feel conflicted if the espresso were delicious, but the service was snide or indifferent. Fortunately I'm looking forward to regular jaunts down the hill for freshly roasted beans.
author: Eliza S.

description: Horribly overpriced for the quality.  Tastes good but definitely not worth anything close to what you pay for it.  Only a true snob would choose their product over the $7.99/lb Jeremiah's French or Italian roast that you can get at Berkeley Bowl and elsewhere.
author: Mizu H.

description: So happy to see my favorite coffee at Paradise Market in Corte Madera!  Now instead of having it UPS'd to me I can just pick it up at this market. This is definitely coffee with a very balanced flavor (non-acidic) with impressive blends and rich aroma.  Always fresh and always consistent in their quality.  I'm proud to be drinking the best.
author: laura w.

description: bottom line mouth watering coffee. so smooth, rich and orgasmic.  man if this place is not out of my way i would be here 24/7.  its ok though alot of good coffee houses in my hood.
author: brian l.

description:
Great people, great coffee.  Been brewing and drinking their coffee for 25+ years.  Always smooth, never bitter.  That was what first hit me with their coffee.  Soooo smooth.  Always have it straight up, black.  Light , dark, mixed,  various grinds, always smoooooth. They have light, dark and all in between.  I get half/half sometimes.
thanks Luch.
author: Richard C.

description: Inviting, strong, and never bitter; just wish I didn't have to go to North Beach to buy it.
author: Rene D.

description: Coffee doesn't get better than this and the staff is great. A simple menu: dark, light and decaff keep everything easy and frequent roasting on ultra-high tech equipment with excellent blends make this a crack-like forming addiction. Enjoy and send some home to the folks.
author: Eric F.

description: Graffeo has changed my life and I'm not kidding.  I love the choice:  Dark or Light.  I love the staff:  The genuine article.  I love the place (s):  No frills storefronts with a giant roasting machine center stage, raw beans in bags piled up everywhere, roasted beans in 50 gallon garbage cans ready for sale, a couple of commercial grinders and a cash register.  But most important I love the beans:  The dark roast produces the best espresso I've ever made (on our Pasquini Livietta).  Friends and neighbors "drop by" unannounced for a cup when they think the machine might be fired up.  And since we moved from Marin (where I used to buy from the San Rafael store) to Los Angeles we continue to buy only Graffeo.  But I miss the ritual of going to the store and taking in the aroma of roasting beans and yapping with the guys behind the counter.  So rather than buy from their convenient online store, I prefer to call them every month or so to place my 3 pound order.  Just the sound of Luigi's familiar voice brings calm to this stormy, impersonal time we live in and gives me a sense of something being right in the world.  And in keeping with their impeccable service, the order arrives almost instantly to my doorstep.  Like I said, Graffeo has changed my life.
author: Patricia G.

description: Hands down the best coffee I have ever had. So good we schlep all the way from South Beach with dog 9it is dog friendly by the way) for two lbs. of dark whole beans
author: Tim H.

description: Ok hard too say this is total 5 I have had better coffee. BUT THIS IS better then a 4. (4.65) and the best I found in SF area,  Really ReallyVERY good coffee. was surprized to have a hard time finding quality coffee in SF   VERYit was. give these guys a visit u will not be disappointed.
author: Sara F.

description: This place is so serious about their coffee that they focus on roasting rather than serving it, despite their ideal North Beach location. They keep it simple: Light Roast, and Dark Roast. That is it.  This coffee will hold up to scrutiny from even the most jaded coffee snobs. If gets less that 5 stars because they keep bankers hours, and it is hard to get there when they are open.
author: Ross J.

description: These beans are the beans. The best beans. Best! I grew up on them.  My folks were such devotees that when the family had to spend six years in the midwest, my mom had the beans regularly shipped back. Nice. I hold Graffeo responsible for my ~30 year habit.
author: Julia W.

description: Take a stroll down Columbus towards Fishermans Wharf & you will be drawn to the intoxicating aroma that wafts through the air on their roasting days. The storefront is sparse & dim & may not seem open for business. Like In-n-Out, the selection is refreshing easy: Dark Roast, Light Roast, Decaf.  The dark roast is so rich & yummy, I left the bag out on the kitchen counter for a couple of hours to saturate the air. This is a full & fulfilling coffee. Try out half pound bags. The folks here are not pretentious as their coffee could warrant.
author: Edwin K.

description: As a former City girl now living in the  gourmet ghetto (Florida), I was thrilled to visit Graffeo on my last visit home.  I called their SF store (415-986-2420 )to find that they open at 9:00 on Saturdays which made for a nice little walk from SOMA.   The gentleman behind the counter was very pleasant and knowlegable and after hearing my coffee stories from Florida, told me I can have Graffeo shipped to me - which I'll do when I'm not planning a visit.  Bought 2 lbs (dark) - put them in my carry on bag and smiled when folks on the plane commented about the rich coffee aroma.  There is no other coffee this smooth and rich.  Heaven!
author: Sabrina B.

description: Graffeo is truly for serious coffee lovers and drinkers. I've been a dark roast fan for 6 years now. The aroma that comes from the bag is amazing and that first sip in the morning is soooo delicious. It's not very close to my neighborhood, but it's well worth the travel time.
author: Michelle N.

description: In the heart of the coffee district, Graffeo remains king. They provide the best coffee beans and coffee grinds specific to your coffeemaker. Only wish they had an adjoining cafe to serve their outstanding coffee...
author: kate p.

description: Hmm, I don't see the draw.  Granted I am a light roast fan and found their light roast non-descript versus others (BB, Ritual, etc.).  Oddly I have purchased beans twice and on both occassions they insisted I get dark roast...whether I am a fan or not...anyhoo...sounds like they do a good job for you dark roast fans out there...
author: Dan G.

description: the dark roast they sell here has to be one of the best, if not the best, coffees i've ever had.  anywhere.  perfectly balanced.  and it's three blocks from my place.  excellent staff and experience - this is the way coffee buying and drinking should be.
author: Matt O.

description: If you're in the area, definitely worth a try.  Great coffee and atmosphere, very San Francisco..
author: Laura K.

description: get the "half and half" mix (I can't remember the real name right now).. this place 1) has the best coffee around and 2) makes the neighborhood smell oh so delicious on roasting days... sigh...
author: Tony C.
